Engine.enginePackage

Class TreeLogger

  • java.lang.Object
    • Engine.enginePackage.TreeLogger
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    EngineLogger

    public class TreeLogger
extends java.lang.Object

    A class for building a log tree. Each node in the log tree is a message, and can have other children messages.

    Building of the tree is done through a current node which can be used to insert new nodes in the tree with insertCurrent(Object[]) and insertChild(Object[]).

    To indicate that children will be inserted for the last child of the current node call the down() method.

    To indicate that all the children of the current node have been inserted, call the up() method after inserting the last child.

    The TreeLogger groups and compresses the nodes as they arrive. The method popCompressedNodes() will return the nodes that have been compressed so far. It is possible that a group of inserted nodes has not been compressed yet, so the method will not return them. To get those nodes you will need to call flushNodes() prior to the call to popCompressedNodes().

    Try to call flushNodes() as sparingly as possible, as it implies some extra overhead.

    The TreeLogger also will block execution of a thread inserting a node if there are too many nodes. This is a practical limit to control memory usage. The nodes must be removed from the tree. Most likely they will be downloaded by the client which uses the engine. The node limit is MAX_BUFFERED_NODES.

    If you don't want to log, just set the logging attribute to false with setLogging(boolean).

                         throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Inserts a new child at the end of the children list of the current node. Then sets the newly inserted child as the current node.

      • down

        public void down()
          throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Sets the current node to be the last child of the current one. Does nothing if there the current node has no child.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • up

        public void up()
        throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Sets the current node to be the parent of the current one. Does nothing is the current node is the root node.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • flushNodes

        public void flushNodes()
